message.content:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: public class FooIterator<E extends Foo> implements Iterator<E> {
  private Iterator<Bar> innerIterator;

  public FooIterator(Collection<Bar> bars) {
    innerIterator = bars.iterator();
  }

  @Override
  public boolean hasNext() {
    return innerIterator.hasNext();
  }

  @Override
  public E next() {
    Bar bar = innerIterator.next();
    try {
      Constructor<E> constructor = (Constructor<E>) bar.getClass().getConstructor(Bar.class);
      return constructor.newInstance(bar);
    } catch (NoSuchMethodException | IllegalAccessException | InstantiationException | InvocationTargetException e) {
      throw new RuntimeException("E does not have an appropriate constructor", e);
    }
  }

  @Override
  public void remove() {
    throw new UnsupportedOperationException("Don't remove from FooIterator!");
  }
}
<<<explanation>>>: In order to ensure that E has a constructor that takes a Bar, you can use a bounded type parameter with the extends keyword. This way, you can specify that E must be a subclass of Foo, which has the required constructor. Inside the next() method, you can use reflection to get the constructor of E and instantiate a new instance using the constructor and the Bar object. If E does not have an appropriate constructor, a runtime exception will be thrown.
